5. Results
5.1. Carbonate leaching tests
Table 1 presents major and trace element data for the ten samples selected for the
carbonate leaching experiments, as well as Li isotope data for five of these samples.
A decrease in the Mg/Ca ratios is observed when 0.1 mol/L HCl is used for leaching
carbonates with higher Mg contents. Considering the high Mg calcite samples (SJL-13, SC-
01, SC-05, SC-20) and the dolomite sample (SC-12), the average of the Mg/Ca ratios drop
from 0.194 in the full dissolution method using 0.5 mol/L HCl to 0.144 reacting samples for 1
hour with 0.5 mol/L HCl and then to 0.08 when dissolving the carbonate phases for 1 hour
with 0.1 mol/L HCl. For the low Mg calcite samples (SJL-05, SL-07, SL-11, SL-21 and SL-
28), the mean of the ratios are constant at 0.002. For the other elements, the concentrations are
highly variable with no direct link to acid strength or percentage of carbonate mass dissolved.
As the most important feature, we highlight the Al and Li concentrations. Samples
SJL-05, SC-05, SC-12 and SC-20 yielded higher Al concentrations when dissolved with 0.1
mol/L. These samples also exhibit higher Li concentrations with this leaching procedure, with
exception of sample SJL-05, which [Li] was below detection limit during the experiments
(Table 1). In all leaching procedures, a positive correlation between Li and Al is observed
(Fig. 4 and Fig. 5).
The Li isotope compositions of the measured sample tests are progressively heavier
from the full dissolution method to the leaching technique using 0.1 mol/L HCl. Sample SC-
05 is an exception, as there is a decrease in the ? 7 Li values when the sample is fully dissolved
with 0.5 mol/L HCl to when the 50% of sample mass is dissolved with the same acid.
Nevertheless, the heaviest composition for this sample is observed when 0.1 mol/L HCl. This
feature occurs even when the decrease or increase in [Li] is not linear among the procedures
194
(Table 1). The Li isotope composition of sample SC-12 was additionally measured in solution
obtained by leaching with 0.1 mol/L acetic acid during 24 hours (20% of sample mass
dissolved). The obtained ? 7 Li value of 11.08 is within the uncertainty of the ?
7 Li value of
10.90 obtained via 0.1 mol/L HCl leaching.
5.1.1. Selection of the most adequate leaching method
The leaching method of carbonates chosen to obtain solutions for Li isotope
measurements is crucial to achieve the preserved isotope record within these marine
precipitates. During such procedures, silicate minerals admixed in the carbonate matrix may
also be leached masking the ? 7 Li values of the carbonate fraction, as these phases are much
more enriched in Li (Pogge von Strandmann et al., 2013). The gain of Li in the analyzed
solution from leached silicates can be monitored by positive correlations between Li vs. Al.
The use of stronger acids and longer reaction times should drive clay mineral leaching rates
higher, thus incrementing the correlation. Not conspicuously, our tests revealed that Li vs. Al
correlation persists in every leaching method (Fig. 4 and Fig. 5). Furthermore, four samples
(SJL-05, SC-05, SC-12 and SC-20) yielded higher [Al] and three of them, higher [Li] (sample
SJL-05 is the exception, Table 1) when leached with 0.1N HCl. This fact seems contradictory
as it means that the weaker acid might have leached more clays than more aggressive
reactions with 0.5 mol/L HCl. Nonetheless, in all cases the 0.1 mol/L HCl leachates displayed
the heavier isotope compositions which suggest less contribution of leached silicates. Apart
from sample SC-05, the measured isotope compositions were progressively lighter when
reacting samples with 0.5 mol/L during one hour and fully dissolving the carbonate fractions
with the same acid, respectively. The Li/Ca vs. ? 7 Licarb plots using the whole set of data
(n=30) obtained via 0.1 mol/L HCl method (Fig. 5) also show that only in section SC (CI-2)
exhibits the expected negative correlation, whereas both SJL and SL sections display a
positive correlation. The case of SJL is emblematic as the carbonates of this section have clay
minerals and micas in their composition, which are more enriched in 6 Li than primary
silicates found in SC section carbonate samples. This is a robust evidence that no systematic
clay leaching is interfering in the Li isotope composition of the carbonate leachates, and is
corroborated by the fact that many leachates obtained with both 0.5 mol/L HCl procedures
yielded lower [Al] and [Li] with lighter Li isotope compositions. Finally, we note that isotope
measurement of the sample SC-12 leached with 0.1N acetic acid resulted in a similar ? 7 Li
195
value as the 0.1 mol/L HCl leachate of the same sample. Pogge von Strandmann et al. (2013)
also showed that leaching procedures using 0.1 mol/L HCl and the Tessier sequential
extraction (Tessier et al., 1979) for carbonate samples yield similar ? 7 Li values within the
uncertainty of the measurements. Therefore, we consider that our elementary and isotopic
data obtained by the 0.1 mol/L HCl leaching method is representative of the seawater from
which the carbonate minerals precipitated, devoid of Li interference from silicates.
In fact, our leaching experiments show that the only geochemical ratio with a linear
relationship with the dissolved carbonate mass percentage is the Mg/Ca ratio (Table 1). The
Mg/Ca ratio from samples containing carbonate phases more enriched in Mg significantly
drops with the use of weaker acids and less time of reaction. As there is no linear relationship
to clay derived elements such as Al and K, we claim that geochemical differences in the
results obtained from multiple leaching methods comes from dissolution of different
carbonate phases rather than from silicate minerals. Secondary diagenetic Mg carbonate
phases (siderite, ankerite, etc.) admixed in the high Mg calcite matrix of the samples may be
responsible for variations in Fe, Mg and Mn concentrations, as well as in Li and ? 7 Li values.
These phases may have been formed from distinct precipitation solutions, so that avoiding
them dissolved in the analytical solution is mandatory to use both Li and Mg isotope
compositions as seawater proxies. In fact, for samples from the SC section (CI-2 part)
secondary dolomite was identified in petrography, around preserved portions of calcite
micrite (Fig. 3D). In this case, it confirms that the calcite phases are primary and should be
the ones analysed. This adds another argument for using the 0.1 mol/L HCl procedure for
leaching carbonate samples of this study, as the procedures using 0.5 mol/L invariably result
in leachates with higher Mg/Ca ratios (Table 1) that suggest contribution from the secondary
carbonates. Nevertheless, this does not explain the high variations of Al concentrations, which
are not conspicuous with leaching of different carbonate phases, and needs additional studies
to determine their causes.
5.2. Major and trace elements data
Table 2 presents major and trace elements data for the 30 carbonate samples of this
study dissolved using 0.1 mol /L HCl for one hour, chosen as the most adequate leaching
procedure for this work. The Li/Ca and Mg/Ca ratios profiles are shown together with the
isotope profile in figures 5 and 6.
196
A significant decrease in the Li/Ca (?mol/mol), Al/Ca (mmol/mol) and Mn/Ca
(mmol/mol) ratios and an increase in the Sr/Ca (mmol/mol) ratios are observed from sections
SJL (CI-1) and SC (CI-2) to section SL (CI-3; Table 2). Furthermore, the Li/Ca and Mn/Ca
are progressively lower upwards stratigraphy, decreasing from mean values of 6.64 in the CI-
1 to 0.78 in the CI-3 for Li/Ca, and from mean values of 0.79 in the CI-1 to 0.14 in the CI-3
for Mn/Ca. A strong positive correlation between Al/Ca and Li/Ca is observed among all
sections (Fig. 5).
The mean values of Mg/Ca ratio vary from 0.037 in the CI-1, to 0.056 in the CI-2 and
to 0.005 in the CI-3, probably reflecting a change in the mineralogy of the Sete Lagoas
Formation. The lower intervals carbonate rocks are mainly composed of high Mg calcite,
whereas the upper interval samples are composed of low Mg calcite. Furthermore, the profile
for the cap carbonate (Fig. 7) shows that both Mg/Ca and Li/Ca ratios are facies dependent
with the mudstones being more enriched in Mg and Li than coarser lithotypes.
5.3. Isotope data
Li, Mg and Sr isotope data for the 30 carbonate samples are exhibited in Table 3 and
their profiles are shown in Fig. 6. The detailed isotope profiles for the basal cap carbonates in
Fig. 7. The detrital fraction of 16 samples had their ? 7 Li values measured (Figs. 6 and 7).
The cap carbonates display 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios ranging from 0.7073 to 0.7118, with an
initial decrease from 0.7099 to its minimum values, followed by a sharp increase to the
maximum value from which the ratios display a decreasing trend upwards (Fig. 7). The Li
isotope record of the CI-1 (section SJL) samples behave similarly to the Sr isotopes in the first
meter of section composed of coarsed grain limestones with aragonite pseudomorphs. The
? 7 Li values drop sharply from 10.04 to 3.38‰ followed by a quick increase to 8.83‰. The
values continue to increase in the high Mg calcite mudstones facies up to 10.24‰ and
fluctuate significantly again in the recristalyzed upper facies where samples SJL-21 and SJL-
26 yielded values of 4.40 and 6.98‰. The analyzed detrital fractions of three samples yielded
similar values around 2.6‰ (Table 3). The ? 26
Mg values in the lowermost facies mirror the
? 7 Li values. An initial increase Mg isotope values from -2.65 to -1.17‰ is sharply followed
by a decrease to -2.58‰. Values are slightly higher in the mudstones but reach the minimum
(-2.91‰) in the uppermost facies.
197
The Sr isotope ratios obtained for the CI-2 (SC section except sample SC-25) range
between 0.7080 and 0.7103. In a general way, there is an increasing upwards trend with
87 Sr/
86 Sr from 0.7080 to 0.7089, with only one radiogenic peak outside this interval observed
on sample SC-12 ( 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratio of 0.7103). A significant drop in the ratios from 0.7089 to
0.7075 from samples SC-24 to SC-25 marks the transition from CI-2 to CI-3 and the
restriction of the basin (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). The Li and the Mg isotope profiles of the
CI-2 part of the SC section have similar mirrored shapes. A base line for the ? 7 Li and ?
26 Mg
values around 16‰ and -3.5‰, respectively, are interrupted by two negative excursions in the
Li isotope record perfectly matched to Mg positive isotope excursions (Fig. 6). Samples SC-
12 and SC-20 display minimum ? 7 Li values of 10.90 and 11.18‰, respectively, and higher
? 26
Mg values of -2.65 and -2.85‰, respectively, for the section. The ? 7 Li values of the
measured detrital fraction of CI-2 samples vary in a narrow range around 6‰, increasing to
7.53‰ in the transition to CI-3.
The 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios of the SL section (CI-3) are much lower than the lower intervals
and oscillate mainly between 0.7074 and 0.7075 with two 0.7078 peaks in the samples SL-30
and SL-33. The ? 7 Li values of the carbonate fraction resemble three increase steps decoupled
from the detrital fraction Li isotope values, which display two increasing upwards cycles from
5 to 8‰ (Fig. 6). The ? 26
Mg values form two increasing upwards cycles. In the first one the
Mg isotope values rise from -2.46 to -0.16‰ and in the second, from -2.55 to -1.19‰ (Fig. 6).
Therefore, the CI-3 records the decoupling of the Mg and Li isotope compositions observed in
the CI-1 and CI-2.

6. Discussion
We analyze the variations of Sr, Mg and Li isotope compositions separately for the
sections SJL, SC and SL as they are representatives of the three different stages of the São
Francisco basin, in which connectivity to the global ocean, weathering and physiographic
conditions might have varied (Paula-Santos et al., 2017).
The SJL section belongs to the lower CI-1 stage, which is interpreted to be deposited
after a glacial period of debatable age (Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014; Babinski et al., 2007;
Caxito et al., 2012; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). Lithologic and ? 13
C data for the carbonate
rocks of the section show that it is base truncated with the lower Carrancas Formation (Paula-
Santos et al., 2017) and do not preserve the distinct cap dolostones with the C negative
excursion found elsewhere on the basin (Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014;
Caxito et al., 2012). Moreover, the recovery of the ? 13
C values in the SJL section from -5 to
0‰ occur in a much thinner stratigraphic interval than in sections up north of the basin
(Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et al., 2014) probably as a result of the shallower settings in
São José da Lapa area.
The very base of the section records coincident sharp decrease in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios
and in the ? 7 Li values and a sharp increase in the ?
26 Mg values (Fig. 7). Enhanced chemical
weathering of silicates could produce both Li (Pogge von Strandmann et al., 2013; Lechler et
al., 2015) and Mg isotope (Kasemann et al., 2014) excursions but cannot explain the
significant decrease in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios from 0.7099 to a minimum in the section of 0.7073,
unless a dominant juvenile igneous mantle source is considered. Although such sources exist,
crustal rocks are dominant in the southern São Francisco craton basement (Teixeira et al.,
2000), so that this possibility is unlikely to be plausible. On the other hand, a carbonate source
could explain the drop down in the Sr isotope ratios but these lithotypes are unlikely to
produce any variations in ? 7 Li values when weathered due to their low [Li] (Burton and
Vigier, 2011; Dellinger et al., 2015) and would likely produce an opposite decrease in the
? 26
Mg values (Pokrovsky et al., 2011; Kasemann et al., 2014). Considering that the
combination of the three isotope systems suggest that this marked variation in the record may
not be caused by enhanced chemical weathering, differences in isotope fractionation driven by
change of the type of the precipitated carbonate should be investigated.
The isotopic variation observed in the base of the CI-1 coincides with a significant
change in the Sr/Ca ratios of the carbonate samples. Sample SJL-05, which yields the
206
anomalous isotope values, displays a Sr/Ca ratio of 3.21 (Table 2) that is six times higher than
other samples in the section. Combined with the presence of aragonite pseudomorphes, this
suggests a change of the precipitated carbonate mineral to aragonite. The ? 7 Liaragonite-solution is
~-11‰, lower than ? 7 Licalcite-solution which is around -3‰ (Marriot et al., 2004), which could
account for the ca 8‰ decrease from sample SJL-03 to SJL-05 and the subsequent increase
observed in the sample SJL-07. The Mg isotope fractionation between precipitate and solution
also decrease from around -2.5‰ in calcite (Immenhauser et al., 2010; Wombacher et al.,
2011; Li et al., 2012) to around -0.9‰ (Wombacher et al., 2011) in aragonite, so that a change
of mineralogy could also explain the higher ? 26
Mg values. Nevertheless, the causes for a
change in the carbonate mineral precipitated are not clear and it alone cannot explain the
decrease in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios. Differences in the carbonate compensation depth in a stratified
water column similar to the Cryogenian and Late Ediacaran “plumeworld” scenarios (Shields,
2005; Liu et al., 2014) could help answering the question, but more detailed analyses in a
more complete sections is needed to investigate these results. We also note that the possible
plume layer effect on the São Francisco basin is located above the cap dolostones, where it is
reported elsewhere (Liu et al., 2014).
Besides mineralogy change, it is also possible that these highly oscillating 87
Sr/ 86
Sr
ratios are a product of diagenesis. The Mn/Sr ratios of sample SJL-05 are much lower than the
other carbonate samples from the section which could suggest Sr leaching and Mn
incorporation in the carbonate crystal structure via diagenetic fluids (Banner and Hanson,
1990; Veizer et al., 1983; Fölling and Frimmel, 2002). The Sr isotopic ratios of the SJL
section are also more radiogenic than those of carbonate rocks from the Sambra section
(Babinski et al., 2007), also from the CI-1 in the southern sector of the basin. If a diagenesis
overprint is assumed, then only the Sr isotopic ratio of sample SJL-05 would be pristine.
Although Mg isotope diagenetic overprint could be safely ruled out as it is strongly rock
buffered, the same is not valid for Li isotopes. Conversely, ? 7 Li and ?
26 Mg values variations
are strongly facies dependent (Fig. 7) and contradict a diagenetic overprint for the whole
section. Based on that, we understand that the set of data here available does not allow a clear
definition of which process caused the pronounced isotope shifts observed at the base of the
SJL section.
Apart from the basal shift, it is notable that the both ? 7 Li and ?
26 Mg values along with
the Mg/Ca and Li/Ca ratios changes vary accordingly to the sedimentary facies (Fig. 7). The
shallower facies from the base and the top of the SJL section display higher ? 7 Li variations
207
together with lower Li/Ca ratios, whereas the deeper high Mg calcite mudstone facies in the
middle portion displays higher and more stable ? 7 Li values and Li/Ca ratios. Similarly, the
? 26
Mg values are more negative and the Mg/Ca ratios are lower in the shallower facies than in
the deeper middle portion. No significant variation of the ? 7 Li values of the detrital fraction is
observed among facies (Fig. 7), so changes in weathering congruency on source areas are
unlikely. We interpret the variations in the shallower phases as a result of the higher
susceptibility of the environment to continental influence under lower sea level stages,
especially at the very base of the section where cross stratification suggests high energy
waters and the Sr isotope shift is observed. Similar results were obtained by Pokrovsky et al.
(2011) in the Siberian Platform. The lowermost CI-1 stage is interpreted as a period of marine
transgression, and the connection of the São Francisco basin to the global isotope pool was
only achieved at the beginning of the CI-2 stage (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). Our isotope,
geochemical and sedimentary data suggest that the transgression was not progressive after the
deposition of the cap dolostones, and the restricted isotope pool during low sea level periods
were subject to freshwater influence.
The co-dependence between isotopic variations and sedimentary facies suggest local
controls on the basin isotope reservoir. Although the negative Li isotope shift at the base is
similar to what is reported for Marinoan cap carbonates (Pogge von Strandmann et al., in
prep) and the Mg positive shift is observed in post-Sturtian cap carbonates (Kasemann,
personal communication), both in Namibia, the excursions in the SJL section occurs above
the ? 13
C minimum, whereas they occur before such minimum in the African successions. This
means that either conditions during recovery from post glacial high pCO2 differed in each
basin (if we assume a Cryogenian age for the glacial deposits in the São Francisco basin) or
that the basal carbonates from the Bambuí Group were deposited after a glacial period when
the Planet did not face Snowball conditions, such as the Ediacaran ones (Ivanov et al., 2013),
and local controls prevailed in the isotope pool. In summary, the present data does not allow
any age inference for the basal cap carbonates of the Sete Lagoas Formation.
After the end of the CI-1 period, both ? 7 Li and ?
26 Mg values reach and stabilize at
around 16 and -3.5‰, respectively, at the SC section (CI-2 stage). The ? 7 Licalcite-solution
between -3 and -5‰ (Marriot et al., 2004) implies that the real seawater value was 19-21‰,
much lower than the 31‰ value of present ocean. Considering the net isotope fractionation of
~16‰ of Li sinks (Misra and Froelich, 2012; Li and West, 2014), the isotope composition of
Li influxes should be of ~3-5‰. If the Li isotope composition of hydrothermal input was not
208
different during Late Ediacaran times, then the mean ? 7 Li of riverine discharge was
significantly lower than the present value of 23‰ (Huh et al., 1998). This means that silicate
weathering dynamics might have been different in the Neoproterozoic plant-free continents,
with less clay mineral formation or different clay mineralogy (Pogge von Strandmann et al.,
in prep), or even by the delivery of chemically immature sediments into marine systems
(Tosca et al., 2010) with significant implications for the composition of dissolved flux.
Considering that the CI-2 stage records a connected phase of the São Francisco basin to the
global pool, this scenario is possible to be found elsewhere in late Ediacaran sections.
Conversely, the ? 26
Mg values of -3.5‰ are the lightest ever reported for the Neoproterozoic
and imply that the real seawater value was around -0.8‰, close to the modern ocean value
(Foster et al., 2010), and a riverine runoff also similar to the present day. The differences in
the Li and Mg systematics may be explained by the fact that Mg isotope fractionation during
pedogenesis is not related to formation of clay minerals but rather to adsorption onto soil
exchange complex (Pogge von Strandmann et al., 2012).
The baseline values are disrupted by two negative Li isotope excursions perfectly
mirrored by Mg positive excursion (Fig. 6). The first excursion peak is also marked by a
maximum in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios of 0.7103 (sample SC-12). Although the same feature is not
observed on the topmost excursion, we note its position on the upper part of the section where
the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr ratios are higher Fig. 6) and possible changes in the Sr influx may not have been
sufficient to change the Sr isotopic values. Additionally, although the higher Mg/Ca ratio of
sample SC-12 could mean that the ? 26
Mg decrease in the sample was driven by a change of
mineralogy, the same cannot be stated to the upper excursion (with no Mg/Ca increment).
Therefore, the similarity of Sr, Li and Mg record argues for a common driver for the
excursions.
The decrease in the ? 7 Li values combined with the increase in the ?
26 Mg and Sr isotopic
values suggest increase in silicate weathering, which could be driven by climatic or
physiographic factors. Such isotope excursions were also observed in carbonate successions
of many periods across the geological record with high atmospheric pCO2 causing enhanced
silicate weathering (Misra and Forelich, 2012; Pogge von Strandmann et al., 2013, in prep.;
Kasemann et al., 2014; Lechler et al., 2015). Strong C isotope shifts also characterized these
periods, which is not the case in the SC section (Paula-Santos et al., 2017) nor in any other
section of the CI-2 in the São Francisco basin (see Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et al., 2007;
2014; Misi et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). Additionally, there are
209
no prominent ? 7 Li value shifts in the detrital mineralogy that argues against a change in the
weathering style. Based on the lack of significant variations in the ? 13
C values in the
carbonate rocks and in the ? 7 Li values of the detrital fraction, we discard a climatic factor.
The physiographic factor seems to better fit the basin scenario. U-Pb ages of detrital zircon
grains retrieved from interbedded siltites and marls from the Sete Lagoas Formation are
consistent with uplift of sources during the deposition on the CI-2 and CI-3 stages (Paula-
Santos et al., 2015). Uplift can significantly increase denudation rates of source areas (Larsen
et al., 2014), thus inhibiting formation of large soil profiles and incongruent weathering. This
is also observed in the detrital fraction ? 7 Li values (Fig. 6): samples from the CI-1 stage have
detrital fraction with lighter Li isotope compositions than the upper intervals, probably
reflecting a change in the contribution from clays derived from larger soil profiles at the base
to more immature sediments in the CI-2 and CI-3. The less retention of 6 Li in clay minerals
(Huh et al., 2001; Vigier et al., 2009; Dellinger et al., 2015) and less 26
Mg adsorption onto
soil exchange complex (Pogge von Strandmann et al., 2012) probably resulted in continental
runoff with lighter Li isotopic composition and heavier Mg isotopic compositions, causing the
observed excursions. Therefore, we interpret the Li and Mg isotope excursions as a response
to upflift and denudation events in the source areas. Seismic sections across the basin point
the Brasília Belt as the main source area for the Bambuí Group and uplift of the orogen at
550-542 Ma is hardly consistent with the evolution of the belt as recorded in its
granitogenesis (Pimentel et al., 2016). Refinements in the timing regarding the flexural
subsidence on the basin induced by the belt and the deposition of the Bambuí Group are still
required. Furthermore, although yet to be investigated in a global scale, similar ? 7 Li trends are
not observed in the late Ediacaran carbonate successions in South China (Ohnemüller, 2014),
what claims for periodical strong local controls on the São Francisco basin isotope pool. This
suggests that although isotope homogenization with the global ocean (Paula-Santos et al.,
2017) and migration of metazoan Cloudina sp. (Warren et al., 2014) occurred, the connection
of the basin achieved during CI-2 stage might have been intermittent, which is consistent with
the central position of the São Francisco Craton in the West Gondwana (Fig. 1; Alkmim et al.,
2006).
The transition to the restricted CI-3 stage recorded in the SL section sets the
decoupling of the ? 7 Li and ?
26 Mg values obtained on the carbonate rocks. The Li isotope
values define three cycles of decrease not linked to the ? 7 Li values in the detrital mineralogy,
which has two decreasing upwards cycles (Fig. 6). On the other hand, the ? 26
Mg values define
210
two increasing upwards cycles that are not linked to changes neither in the carbonate
mineralogy nor in the Mg/Ca ratios. Increased silicate weathering could explain the rise in the
? 26
Mg values, but this finds no support in the Li isotope record. Increment in the precipitation
rates could also drive more positive Mg isotopic values (Immenhauser et al., 2010;
Mavromatis et al., 2013), but the change in the rates would have to be strongly significant to
produce a ~2‰ difference in 10 m interval in the section. When compared to additional
geochemical data, the increase in the ? 26
Mg values perfectly mirror decrease in the Sr/Ca
ratios (Fig. 6). Therefore, these variations can better be explained by cycles of depletion on
the seawater reservoir by carbonate precipitation, removing 24
Mg and Sr (which involves no
isotope fractionation) from the water column. As carbonate precipitation is a negligible Li
sink (Misra and Froelich, 2012; Li and West, 2014), such processes have little effect on the
? 7 Li values of the carbonate samples.
Depletion of the reservoir implies that the sink surpassed the influx of Mg and Sr to
the basin, refilling the pool only sporadic and ending the cycles. This scenario seems
incompatible with the tectonic framework of the São Francisco basin at the Ediacaran-
Cambrian transition, once it was surrounded by orogens and thus restricted (Fig. 1). Large
portions of exposed continental crust are expected to result in a large nutrient influx derived
from silicate weathering to marine systems, which is a possible cause for the appearance of
complex life forms at the end of Proterozoic (Meert and Liebermann, 2008; Santosh, 2010;
Ganade-Araújo et al., 2014). We note however, that this is not a simple picture and the
position of the marine basins in relation to the sources may play a significant role on the
dissolved influx (Fig. 8).
The restriction of the São Francisco basin was probably caused by uplift of the
surrounding orogens accompanied by a higher siliciclastic influx in the upper Sete Lagoas,
Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations (CI-3 stage – Dardenne, 1978;
Martins-Neto et al., 2001; Alkimim and Martins-Neto, 2012) as a result of higher denudation
rates on the source areas, which is expected in highland areas (Larsen et al., 2014). Increased
denudation combined to lower water/rock reaction time due to steepened topography may
have diminished the weathering intensity in the orogens (Bouchez et al., 2014), thus
decreasing the dissolved influx of the runnof derived from silicate weathering. In modern
settings, such as the Amazonian River basin, the sediments eroded in the highland areas
become available for weathering in the flood plains (Fig. 8 - Bouchez et al., 2014; Dellinger
et al., 2015). Therefore, the final silicate weathering influx to the ocean is higher. In the case
211
of the São Francisco basin, the proximity of the basin to the mountain ranges changed the
scenario (Fig. 8). The eroded load from the orogens was possibly delivered and stored in the
basin, where they were not available for weathering. Seawater from the basin collected
freshwaters with low silicate weathering influx straight from the highlands. This would
explain the decrease in the Mg and Sr influxes. In such scenario, a larger 6 Li influx would be
expected (Dellinger et al., 2015), and so lighter Li isotope compositions in the SL section
carbonate rocks. This is not observed as the ? 7 Li values of the section are in the same range of
the SC section. But we note that a major increase in the Sr/Ca ratios (~4 times in average)
occurs between these sections. Although not conclusive, the change to low calcite Mg may
represent the meta-stable phase of primary aragonite, which would signify a much lower
? 7 Licalcite-solution (Marriot et al., 2004), so that the real seawater composition is considerably
lighter.
Together with the low silicate weathering influx, the lower reaction water/rock time
due to steepened topography probably increased carbonate/silicate dissolution ratio (Palmer
and Edmond, 1992; Blum et al., 1998). The result is the major drop down in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr
ratios, larger HCO3 - ionic influx (Palmer and Edmond, 1992), subsequent development of
REE shale normalized “seawater” distribution from the CI-2 to CI-3 (Paula-Santos et al.,
submitted), and a major change in the nutrient type influx to the São Francisco basin. The
lower contribution of dissolved influx from silicates could mean less availability of P and K
nutrients in the basin. At first, this seems inconsistent with a high bioproductivity suggested
by the positive ? 13
C values of the CI-3 (Santos et al., 2000; Vieira et al., 2007; Alvarenga et
al., 2014; Paula-Santos et al., 2017), as these nutrients would limit photosynthesis. However,
biological experiments in microalgae show that supply of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC)
controls PO4 3 - uptake during photosynthesis, and is a more important limiter for this process
than NPK type nutrients (Huertas et al., 2000). The larger HCO3 - ionic influx from carbonate
weathering probably kept a large DIC reservoir in the basin. Also, cyanobacteria species that
use bicarbonate as DIC source are favoured in environments with high [HCO3 - ] (Miller and
Colman, 1980; Prins and Elzenga, 1989). These organisms develop higher rates of
photosynthesis compared to organisms that use CO2 as DIC source (Badger et al., 1980;
Miller and Colman, 1980; Lucas, 1983; Prins and Elzenga, 1989) thus explaining the positive
? 13
C values of the CI-3 carbonate rocks. Furthermore, restriction plus low silicate weathering
intensity probably decreased the sulphate availability in basinal seawater, inhibiting bacterial
sulphate reduction and triggering methanogenic archea activity that drove the very positive
212
? 13
C values in the carbonate fraction. Finally, it is also notable the lack of any kind of
complex fauna in the Bambuí Group atop the Cloudina sp. occurrences so far. The type of
nutrient influx together with other environmental conditions, such as anoxia (Paula-Santos et
al., submitted), may have played an important role inhibiting life diversification in the São
Francisco basin.
The Bambuí Group case illustrates how environmental conditions may have been
different among Ediacaran-Cambrian basins, especially between the global ocean and inland
epicontinental seas. For instance, nutrient influx varied significantly among them and
different biological responses are expected. This should be carefully considered when
analyzing the causes of the movement of life to its complex forms and the timing of such
event in different geological records worldwide.
213

7. Conclusions
- Our carbonate leaching experiments show that secondary carbonate mineralogy also
plays an important role on the Li isotope composition of samples. Stronger acids and longer
reaction times lead to dissolution of secondary high Mg calcite and dolomite in the case of the
Bambuí Group samples. This adds a further factor of caution (besides clay mineral leaching)
during sample dissolution for Li isotope analyses and experiments should be performed for
different sets of sample.
- Sr, Li and Mg isotope data variations for the basal carbonates of the Bambuí Group
(CI-1 stage) are facies dependent and show the importance of local controls on the basin
during this stage. The exception is the major shift in the ? 7 Li, ?
26 Mg values and
87 Sr/
86 Sr
ratios in one sample on the very base of the SJL section that can be result of enhanced silicate
weathering in source areas, similar to what is observed in other Neoproterozoic cap
carbonates. However, our data is not sufficient to determine this and change in mineralogy of
the precipitated carbonate is also a possible explanation for the shift.
- We report ? 7 Li values for seawater much lower than present day for the connected
stage of the São Francisco basin and that can be representative for global ocean at the Late
Ediacaran. Unless the Li sinks in the ocean were significantly different than nowadays, clay
mineral type and formation may have varied through time. Conversely, the ? 26
Mg values of
the same stage are closer to modern ocean value.
- The Li and Mg isotopic excursions from the connected stage (CI-2) are compatible
with uplifting of source areas during Ediacaran-Cambrian. If the Brasilia belt is one of those
areas (as shown by seismic sections), refinements in the evolution of the São Francisco basin
subsidence and filling are required. Moreover, these excursions suggest that such connection
was probably intermittent so the basin was sporadically subject to local controls.
- The geochemical and isotope data from the restricted stage (CI-3) show that the basin
experienced a significant decrease in the dissolved influx from silicate weathering due to high
denudation rates in source areas and storage of the eroded sediments inside the basin.
214
Changes in the nutrient type delivered into the basin may explain the present lack of a robust
Ediacaran-Cambrian fauna above the Cloudina sp. stratigraphy position in the Bambuí Group.
Although exposure of continental crust might have delivered nutrients derived from higher
silicate weathering rates to the late Ediacaran ocean, the position of inland seas in relation to
the highland areas is crucial to determine whether such nutrients reached these seas or not.
This should be considered when analysing the relationship between nutrient and life
diversification among different geological settings in this period.

6.4. Geocronologia
Os dados de geocronologia U-Pb e Hf obtidos em grãos de zircão detrítico e Sm-Nd
em amostras de rocha total são apresentados e discutidos no artigo científico “Sedimentary
provenance of the São Francisco basin in its southern sector, SE Brazil”, submetido ao
periódico Brazilian Journal of Geology.
Os dados obtidos sugerem uma única reorganização na captação de sedimentos para a
Bacia do São Francisco durante a deposição das unidades basais glaciais e das formações Sete
Lagoas, Serra de Santa Helena e Lagoa do Jacaré. Esta reorganização ocorre na passagem da
fácies conglomerática para as fácies finas da Formação Carrancas. Durante a deposição dos
conglomerados, vales incisos no embasamento recebiam sedimentos exclusivamente das
paredes destes vales. Com a transgressão marinha e aumento da área de deposição dos siltitos
o número de fontes contribuindo para o preenchimento da bacia se diversifica e permanece
semelhante durante a deposição de boa parte do Grupo Bambuí. Isto se coloca como mais um
argumento contra a existência de um hiato significativo na base da Formação Sete Lagoas.
Considerando a presença do fóssil índice Cloudina sp. na porção intermediária desta unidade,
torna-se complicado atribuir uma idade Criogeniana para a glaciação da Bacia do São
Francisco, que provavelmente teria ocorrido no Ediacarano médio ou tardio com vários
correlatos pelo globo. Se uma discordância ainda não identificada existe, a idade absoluta da
capa carbonática corresponde ao argumento mais robusto para sugerir que a glaciação é
Sturtiana (~720 Ma).
Os dados deste trabalho não permitem distinguir se as fontes ativas na deposição do
Grupo Bambuí se encontravam nas faixas Brasília ou Araçuaí, o que poderia ser uma
informação significativa no entendimento da evolução da Bacia do São Francisco.
226
Sedimentary provenance of the São Francisco basin in its southern sector, SE Brazil
Gustavo M. Paula-Santos 1 and Marly Babinski
1
1 Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo; Rua do Lago, 562 – Cidade
Universitária, São Paulo, SP, Brazil – ZIP code 05508-080; gustavomps@yahoo.com.br
Abstract
We present new Sm-Nd, U-Pb and Hf isotope geochronological data for the
siliciclastic rocks of the São Francisco basin in its southern sector. The obtained Sm-Nd TDM
ages for the Carrancas conglomerates range between 2.7 and 3.3 Ga with ?Nd(550 Ma) values
lower than -17. An abrupt change in the data is observed in the transition to the finer grain
facies of the Carrancas Formation and the Moema Laminites, in which the Sm-Nd TDM ages
range from 1.4 to 2.1 Ga with ?Nd(550 Ma) values between -9.46 and –5.59. No significant
changes in the spectrum of ages occur in the upper Bambuí Group that yielded Sm-Nd TDM
ages between from 1.3 to 2.0 Ga with ?Nd(550 Ma) values between -9.53 to -4.09. The lack of
reorganization in the sources capitation from the lower glacial units to the upper carbonate-
siliciclastic adds another argument to dismiss an unconformity within the Bambuí Group. The
presence of the index fossil Cloudina sp. in the lower Sete Lagoas Formation makes the
glaciation probably Ediacaran in age. If an unconformity exists, we stick to the only absolute
age provided so far for the cap carbonates to claim the glaciation is Sturtian. U-Pb ages for
detrital zircons of the Bambuí Group range from the Archean to the Early Ediacaran. Hf
isotope analyses in the Ediacaran (ca. 630 Ma) grains point to a source with long crustal
residence time, as shown by exclusively negative ?Hf(t) values. However, the current data is
insufficient to distinguish the contribution from sources in the Brasília and Araçuaí belts.
Keywords: detrital zircon U-Pb dating, Sm-Nd provenance, Carrancas Formation, Moema
Laminite, Bambuí Group
1. Introduction
The geological history of the São Francisco basin (east-central Brazil; Fig. 1) is a
puzzle with many implications for the West Gondwana assembly at the Ediacaran-Cambrian
mailto:gustavomps@yahoo.com.br
227
boundary. A large data set show that its sedimentary rocks were deposited in a foreland basin
set over the homonymous craton as a response to the crustal load of the western Brasília Belt
(Fig. 1). Intriguingly, the timing of the deposition of most of the sediments is constrained
around 550 Ma (Warren et al., 2014; Paula-Santos et al., 2015), which is much younger than
the orogen?s metamorphic peak (~630 Ma; Pimentel et al., 1999; Pimentel, 2016). Although
the Brasília belt has a wide range of magmatic rocks spanning through the Ediacaran, the
plutonism dated at ca. 540 Ma is considered anorogenic (Pimentel, 2016), meaning that
refinements in the timing regarding the subsidence and filling of the São Francisco basin still
needs to be done. Also, at ca. 550 Ma the Araçuaí orogen was already built at the eastern
margin of the craton (Fig. 1; Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011), but its contribution to the basin
filling is not fully understood and seismic sections show the belt mainly as a deformer of the
sediments with hardly any sedimentation wedge over the craton (Zalán and Romeiro-Silva,
2007). Sources dated at ca. 560 Ma are described in the Southern Brasília Orogen (Coelho et
al., 2017) and in the Ribeira Belt (Heilbron et al., 2008) to the south of the São Francisco
Craton, so that they may also have contributed to the basin filling.
Besides that, researchers have not achieved an agreement about the age of the
glaciation recorded at the base of the Bambuí Group, the main geological unit of the São
Francisco basin. This unit comprises carbonate-siliciclastic rocks that overly the basal
glaciogenic deposits of the Jequitaí Formation and its correlatives in the cratonic and marginal
belts area. The basal unit of the Bambuí Group is the Sete Lagoas Formation (Fig. 2),
composed dominantly by carbonate rocks with very negative ? 13
C values at the very base
(Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014; Vieira et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Kuchenbecker et al.,
2016; Paula-Santos et al., 2017). This geological record is conspicuous with the Snowball
hypothesis (Hoffman et al., 1998; Hoffman and Schrag, 2002) that postulate at least three
periods of extreme climatic shifts during the Cryogenian and Ediacaran (Halverson et al.,
2005), named: Sturtian (~720 Ma), Marinoan (~635 Ma) and Gaskiers (~582 Ma).
Babinski et al. (2007) dated the cap carbonates of the Sete Lagoas Formation at 740 ±
22 Ma (Pb-Pb isochron age) and correlated the glaciation of the São Francisco basin to the
Sturtian period. On the other hand, Caxito et al. (2012) and Alvarenga et al. (2014) proposed a
Marinoan age for the glaciation based on isotope chemostratigraphy on the overlying
carbonate rocks. The presence of the index fossil Cloudina sp. at the middle portion of the
Sete Lagoas Formation (Warren et al., 2014) implies for both Cryogenian ages that either an
unconformity yet to be found separates the cap carbonates from the rest of the Bambuí Group,
or the Sete Lagoas Formation records the entire Ediacaran period in approximately 100 m of
228
stratigraphy. Based on stratigraphic and chemostratigraphic analysis, Kuchenbecker et al.
(2016) concluded that the existence of an unconformity is unlikely and proposed that the basal
diamictites may be Late Ediacaran in age.
Under this debate we present new Sm-Nd data for the siliciclastic rocks of the Bambuí
Group and its basal glaciogenic deposits. Additionally, U-Pb SHRIMP ages and Hf isotope
data of detrital zircon grains retrieved from a sandstone sample of the Serra de Santa Helena
Formation (Fig. 2) are also presented. This work is an effort to track the sedimentary sources
of the São Francisco basin and its relationship with the surrounding orogens, as well as to
shed light on the age of the glacial rocks.
2. Geological setting
The São Francisco basin comprises Neoproterozoic-Cambrian sedimentary rocks that
cover more than 300,000 km 2 of the homonymous craton in east central Brazil (Fig. 1).
Exposures of the basement (>1.8 Ga) occur in the southern and north-eastern area of the
craton (Teixeira et al., 2000; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012).
The base of the sedimentary cover is composed of sparse glacial units of mainly
continental origin of the Jequitaí Formation (Rocha-Campos and Hasui, 1981; Karfunkel and
Hoppe, 1988; Martins-Neto and Hercos, 2002). In spite of several tectonic discontinuities, the
glacial unit has correlates in the craton?s marginal belts: the Macaúbas Group in the Araçuaí
Belt and the Ibiá Group on the Brasília Belt (Uhlein et al., 1999; Dardenne, 2000; Martins-
Neto et al., 2001; Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011; Babinski et al., 2012). In the cratonic area, the
Carrancas Formation (Dardenne, 1978; Vieira et al., 2007; Uhlein et al., 2012) and the
Moema Laminites (Rocha-Campos et al., 2011) are the correlates that occur in the southern
sector of the São Francisco basin, although the glacial origin of the first unit is debatable
(Caxito et al., 2012; Uhlein et al., 2016).
The Bambuí Group is the main unit of the São Francisco basin and is composed of
carbonate-siliciclastic rocks that either overlie the glacial unit or is in sharp contact atop the
basement (Dardenne, 1978). It records a marine transgression in a foreland basin set over the
craton in response to the Brasília and Araçuaí belts crustal overload and outcrops throughout
the craton and the western Brasília Belt, but not in eastern orogen (Martins-Neto et al., 2001;
Zalán and Romeiro-Silva, 2007; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; Reis and Suss, 2016).
Shear zones with well developed foliation and stretching lineation separate basement and
sedimentary cover, and the metamorphism in the studied area is low graded.

Dardenne (1978) subdivided the Bambuí Group in five units (Fig. 2), from base to top:
(i) Sete Lagoas Formation that is composed of limestones and dolostones with interbedded
marls and siltites (thickness ? 500 m); (ii) Serra de Santa Helena Formation, which comprises
mainly siltstones with interbedded shales, sandstones and limestones (640 m); (iii) Lagoa do
Jacaré Formation that consists in oolitic limestones, siltstones and marlstones (350 m); (iv)
Serra da Saudade Formation, which displays siltstones, green shale and minor occurrences of
limestones (100 m); and (v) Três Marias Formation, constituted by arkosic sandstones and
siltstones (100 m). The thicknesses here shown were extracted from Iglesias and Uhlein
(2009).
The age of the rocks of the São Francisco basin remains controversial, especially the
glacial deposits. The basal carbonate rocks of the Sete Lagoas Formation display very
negative ? 13
C values, similar to other Neoproterozoic cap carbonates (Alvarenga et al., 2007,
2014; Vieira et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). Babinski et al.
(2007) obtained a Pb-Pb isochron age of 740 ± 22 Ma in these carbonates and correlated the
glaciation to the Sturtian global event. Other researchers did not follow this dating and
claimed a Marinoan age (~635 Ma) based on the negative carbon excursion found in these
carbonates and on Sr isotope chemostratigraphy (Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2014).
But the recent findings of Cloudina sp. (Warren et al., 2014) and detrital zircons with U-Pb
around 560 Ma (Paula-Santos et al., 2015; Fig. 2) in the Sete Lagoas Formation show that
most of the Bambuí Group is Late Ediacaran / Early Cambrian in age. Unless a major
unconformity between the cap carbonates and the rest of the deposits of the São Francisco
basin is assumed, the glaciogenic units are also likely to be Late Ediacaran in age
(Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). So far, such sedimentary hiatus has not been described.
2.1. Description of samples
Two samples of diamictite from the Carrancas Formation (Table 1) were collected
(Fig. 2). The outcrops consist of monomitic to oligomitic matrix supported conglomerate
deposited in basement valleys. The clasts are sub-angular to sub-rounded, with size ranging
between 2 and 20 cm (largest side) and are dominantly composed of igneous rocks from the
valley walls, with subordinated quartz vein fragments (Fig. 3A). The matrix has a greenish
colour and comprises quartz and feldspar silt/sand with minor occurrences of carbonate
cement. The size of the clasts decrease upwards and the diamictite grades to orange / pink
siltites with planar lamination. One sample from these siltites was collected.
232
Nine samples of the Moema Laminites were collected from two different localities. At
SAFFRAN quarry (Fig. 2; Fig. 3B), mudstone (sample MG04-41A) and varvite facies
(MG02-14B) of the glacial succession were sampled. Striations in the bedding plane suggest
that the sea ice touched the bottom of the basin during deposition (Rocha-Campos et al.,
2011). The remaining samples were collected between Formiga and Bom Despacho cities
(Fig. 2), where a sole glacial advance is recorded in a deformed tillite overlain by a post-
glacial laminate (Rocha-Campos et al., 2011). Varvite (n=2; Table 1), siltite (n=3) and
mudstone facies (n=2) of the glacial succession were sampled.
Ten samples from the Sete Lagoas Formation were collected, covering the three
Chemostratigraphic Intervals (CI) proposed by Paula-Santos et al. (2017). One marl sample
(P6, Table 1) interbedded CI-1 cap carbonates was retrieved in the Sambra quarry (for
detailed stratigraphy see Vieira et al., 2007). We also collected eight samples of siltites from
centimetric (5 to 15 cm thick) siliciclastic layers interbedded in the impure carbonate rocks of
the CI-2 (Fig 2, Table 1). Finally one marlstone interbedded in the dark grey limestones of the
CI-3 (GPP-M) was sampled (Fig. 3C).
Eight samples from the Serra de Santa Helena Formation spread through the south of
the São Francisco basin were used in this study (Fig. 2). Five of them are siltites, which are
the dominant lithotype of the unit (Fig. 3D), and three are sandstones found in some locations.
Finally, two samples of the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation were collected. Sample LJ-A is
a fine sandstone interbedded in the oolitic dark grey limestones (Fig. 3E), whereas sample
FAS-LJ is siltite layer (Fig. 3F) described within tilted limestones with carbonate intraclasts.

3. Analytical procedures
234
Thirty two samples were analyzed for Sm-Nd isotopic composition. Samples P12 of
the Carrancas Formation, P6 and GPP-M of the Sete Lagoas Formation, P2SH from the Serra
de Santa Helena Formation, and LJ-A and FAS-LJ from the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation
yielded enough zircon grains for U-Pb dating and Hf isotope analyses. Other samples did not
provide enough of these minerals for U-Pb provenance. All the sample preparation steps and
isotope analyses were carried out at the Geochronological Research Center (CPGeo) of the
University of São Paulo.
For the Sm and Nd isotopic analyses, whole rock samples were powdered and
dissolved with HF, HNO3 and HCl. Purification of Sm and Nd was performed by standard ion
exchange procedures using RE and LN Eichron resins. Isotope data was obtained by Thermal
Ionization Mass Spectrometry (TIMS) using a Triton mass spectrometer (Thermo Fischer,
Germany). The measured 143
Nd/ 144
Nd ratios were normalized to 0.7129 (DePaolo, 1981). The
mean value of the 143

was 0.512102 ± 0.000002 (1?). The Sm-Nd model ages are reported based on the depleted
mantle model (DePaolo, 1981) and are considered mean crustal residence ages. The fSm/Nd and
?Nd(550 Ma) parameters were calculated according to Hamilton et al. (1983) for an age of 550Ma
for the sediments (see item 5).
Detrital zircon grains from samples were separated using standard heavy liquid and
magnetic procedures. The U-Pb analyses were performed in a multi collector SHRIMP IIe
(ASI, Australia). Grains were arranged in an epoxy mount together with the Temora zircon
standard (417 Ma; Black et al., 2003), polished to expose their cores and covered with gold
coating for internal cathodoluminescence imaging and dating. For age determination, five
scans through the mass stations were made. U concentrations were calibrated using the SL13
standard (U = 238 ppm, Williams, 1998) and 206

4. Results
4.1. Sm-Nd isotope data
Table 1 exhibits the Sm-Nd isotopic results. The diamictite samples from the
Carrancas Formation yielded the oldest Sm-Nd TDM ages: 2.7 and 3.3 Ga (Table 1; Fig. 4) on
samples MG08-04 and MG03-27A, respectively. The ?Nd(550 Ma) values of these rocks are also
the most negative, -25.09 and -17.98 for the respective samples above, suggesting sources of
long crustal residence time. These values are consisted with the data reported by Guacaneme
et al. (submitted) for a diamictite of the same unit in the Inhaúma city area (Table 1). The
authors obtained a Sm-Nd TDM age of 2.5 Ga and an ?Nd(550 Ma) value of -23.90. The transition
to the siltite facies of the unit is marked by an abrupt shift to a younger age (Fig. 4). Sample
P12 display a Sm-Nd TDM age of 1.5 Ga and an ?Nd(550 Ma) value of -8.26. Although, sources of
long crustal residence were still active, contribution from younger rocks is more important in
the fine grained facies. The Moema Laminite fine grained rocks also have model ages
considerably younger than the diamictites. The Sm-Nd TDM ages vary from 1.4 to 2.1 Ga with
?Nd(550 Ma) values are between -9.46 and -5.59 (Table 1).
Overall, the samples from the overlying Bambuí Group yielded Sm-Nd isotopic results
similar to the fine grained sediments from Carrancas Formation and Moema Laminites (Fig.
4). The Sm-Nd TDM ages are within the 1.3-2.0 Ga interval and the ?Nd(550 Ma) values range
from -9.53 to -4.09 (Table 1), also suggesting sources of long crustal residence time. The marl
sample from the basal CI-1 of the Sete Lagoas Formation has a model age of 1.7 Ga.
Obtained ages for the CI-2 are within the 1.5-1.8 Ga interval, which is younger than ages
obtained for the same CI by Paula-Santos et al. (2015; 1.8-2.0 Ga) in the south-eastern limit
236
of the São Francisco basin. The marlstone sample (GPP-M) of the upper CI-3 of the unit has
model ages of 1.6 Ga, also younger than the one obtained by those authors (1.8 Ga). The
Serra de Santa Helena Formation rocks yielded Sm-Nd TDM ages between 1.5-2.0 Ga and the
Lagoa do Jacaré Formation samples FAS-LJ and LJ-A have Sm-Nd TDM ages of 1.3 and 1.6
Ga, respectively. The average of the ?Nd(550 Ma) values for the Sete Lagoas Formation are
slightly more negative than the average from combined Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do
Jacaré formations: -7.85 and -5.93, respectively.
4.2. U-Pb ages and Hf isotope data of detrital zircons
Attempts to retrieve detrital zircon grains from the samples were made, but only four
samples provided enough of these minerals for U-Pb and Hf isotope provenance studies: (i)
GPP-M from the upper Sete Lagoas Formation (CI-3, Table 2); (ii) P2SH from the Serra de
Santa Helena Formation (Table 3); (iii) FAS-LJ (Table 4) and (iv) LJ-A (Table 5), both from
the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation. Enough dated zircons with ages within 10% discordance for
population probability calculation were obtained only for samples P2SH and FAS-LJ. The Hf
isotope data was obtained for the Late Cryogenian / Early Ediacaran grains from the sample
P2SH as an effort to track the sources of the zircons (Table 6). Additionally, fifteen grains
from sample P6 were dated, but less than half of the ages were concordant (Table 7, n=7). The
concordant U-Pb ages vary from 2050 to 448 Ma. Most of the ages younger than 630 Ma
were obtained in grains with high common lead, except one grain that yielded an age of 531 ±
25 Ma.
Sample GPP-M provided colourless subeuhedral and reddish rounded grains with
largest side (or diameter) sizes ranging from 80 to 200 ?m and igneous oscillatory zoning
(Fig. 5). The Concordia diagram (Fig. 6A) show age concentrations at 800, 1200 and 2000
Ma, but two sets of grains also plot discordias with superior intercepts close to 2200 and 2800
Ma, and lower intercepts towards Neoproterozoic suggesting Pb loss at this time. The
retrieved grains from sample P2SH are yellowish, euhedral to sub-euhedral with largest side
of ca 100 ?m and igneous oscillatory zoning (Fig. 5). The obtained U-Pb ages define a single
dominant population aged around 630 Ma (Fig. 6B and Fig. 7A) and a Concordia age of 631
± 5 Ma (Fig. 5B). The ?Hf(t) values of the grains are negative and vary from -13.94 to -5.36
and the Hf TDM ages are between 1.9 to 2.4 Ga (Table 6; Fig. 8). Zircon grains retrieved from
sample FAS-LJ are colourless, sub-euhedral to sub-rounded and largest side ranging from 80
237
to 150 ?m. The grains display mainly igneous oscillatory zoning (Fig. 5). The main age
populations (30% of the grains each) are dated at ca. 810 and 950 Ma (Fig. 6C and 7B). Two
populations between 1100 and 1200 Ma are defined by 20% of the grains. Minor populations
(<5%) are dated between 1400 and 2200 Ma and four grains displayed Archean ages. Sample
LJ-A provided mainly euhedral to subeuhedral colourless zircons with largest side ranging
from 70 to 250 ?m (Fig. 5). Concordant zircon grains are dated between 600 and 1100 Ma
(Fig. 6D).

5. Discussions
5.1. Sedimentary Provenance and tectonic implications
Our Sm-Nd data suggest little variation in the sedimentary sources active during the
deposition of most of the basal glaciogenic units and the Bambuí Group (Fig. 4). The
exception is the diamictite facies of the Carrancas Formation, which yielded Archean TDM
ages (Table 1). Although the abrupt shift in the ages between the coarser and finer sediments
252
could suggest a possible unconformity in the lower portion of the São Francisco basin, it may
occur due to change in the basin sediment feeding in response to the marine transgression that
flooded the craton.
Provenance studies in the Carrancas Formation conglomerates show that it is mainly
monomitic (Guacaneme et al., submitted) to oligomitic (Kuchenbecker, 2011; Vieira et al.,
2007). The occurrence of the unit described by Guacaneme et al. (submitted) in Inhaúma city
area is emblematic, as the conglomerate is clearly deposited in a basement valley and has only
clasts of the leucogranite observed in the valley walls. The U-Pb data of detrital zircons of the
Carrancas conglomerate also point to a dominant Archean source (Kuchenbecker, 2011;
Guacaneme et al., submitted) with only a few zircon grains older or younger than this main
source, which is consistent with the age of basement in the southern sector of the basin
(Teixeira et al., 2000). These studies agree with our Sm-Nd TDM ages and negative ?Nd(550 Ma)
values (Table 1; Fig. 4), that suggest Archean basement sources with very long crustal
residence time. Similar results were also obtained for the Carrancas Formation by Uhlein et
al. (2016). This data set is compatible with a very close igneous source for the conglomerates
and a small area of sediment sources, derived mainly from the basement valley walls in which
they deposited (Vieira et al., 2007; Guacaneme et al., submitted). As transgression progressed
and flooded the craton, the area of sedimentation extrapolated the limits of these valleys,
resulting in deposition of the fine sediments in a larger area and apparently increasing the
capitation of sources that were initially restricted to the valley walls. These new sources were
potentially younger than the Archean ones. This episode is recorded in the transition to the
finer facies in the Carrancas Formation and in the Moema Laminites and their younger Sm-
Nd TDM ages and less negative ?Nd(550 Ma) values. The diversification of sources may be also
recorded in U-Pb ages observed in detrital zircon grains of the Carrancas Formation siltites
(sample P12, Table 7). Although our U-Pb data for these rocks are not proper to a reliable
provenance study, the most concordant ages (discordance ? 3%) are from the Staterian
(~1900 Ma) and Ediacaran (600 Ma) periods. We also note that these data are not adequate to
constrain the maximum depositional age of the Carrancas Formation.
On the other hand, the transition from the finer facies of the Carrancas Formation and
the Moema Laminites to the Bambuí Group is not marked by any significant changes in the
Sm-Nd TDM ages and ?Nd(550 Ma) values. Sm-Nd isotopic data from bulk rock sediments may
not be the most adequate system to constrain the timing of the deposition, as the TDM ages
represent a mixture of sources and rocks with younger detrital zircons may yield older TDM
253
ages (Paula-Santos et al., 2015). Nevertheless, the striking similarity of the data from those
units suggests that sources with similar origin were active during most of the deposition of the
São Francisco basin. The database of U-Pb dating in detrital zircons from the Bambuí Group
also show a wide range of sources spanning from the Archean to the Early Cambrian
(Pimentel et al., 2011; Kuchenbecker, 2014; Paula-Santos et al., 2015; this work), which is
consistent with our interpretation for the Sm-Nd data. Although not conclusive, this range of
U-Pb ages is similar to the observed in the few grains of the Carrancas Formation siltite
(sample P12; Table 7), what adds another argument to similarity of sources through the
deposition of the lower units and the Bambuí Group. However, tracking whether these
sources are located in the Brasília or in the Araçuaí belt is not a single task.
The TDM ages between 1.3 and 2.1 Ga and ?Nd(550 Ma) values between -9.53 to -4.09 are
compatible with the Sm-Nd signatures of igneous rocks from both the western Brasília
(Pimentel et al., 1999, 2016) and the eastern Araçuaí belt (Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011). Our
exclusively negative ?Hf(t) values do not help solving the question as they mainly point to
sources with long crustal residence time. The U-Pb ages of the detrital zircon grains from
sample P2SH (Serra de Santa Helena Formation) are also dubious. The data indicate a single
dominant source of ca. 630 Ma (Figs. 6B and 7A). Igneous rocks with this U-Pb age are also
found in both orogens. Collisional magmatism from the Late Cryogenian / Early Ediacaran
periods is reported in the Brasília Belt (Valeriano et al., 2008; Seer and Moraes, 2013) and in
the Rio Doce magmatic arc from the Araçuaí belt (Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2007; Tedeschi,
2013). The Archean and Paleoproterozoic zircon grains from the studied samples are derived
from sources of the São Francisco basin basement (Teixeira et al., 2000). Sources in the 1400-
1050 Ma interval are currently known only in the Araçuaí belt. Zircon grains from crystal-tuff
(Guadagnin et al., 2013) and volcano-clastic rocks (Chaves et al., 2013) were dated between
1.4-1.0 Ga in the Espinhaço Supergroup. However, detrital zircon populations within this
interval age were obtained in the Macaúbas Group (Babinski et al., 2012) and in the
Espinhaço Supergroup (Valladares et al., 2004; Valeriano et al., 2004; Chemale et al., 2012),
both located in the eastern belt, and in the Paranoá, Canastra, Araxá and Ibiá groups in
western belt (Pimentel et al., 2011; Pimentel, 2016). Although primary source are located to
the east of the craton, one cannot rule out that these detrital grains are reworked from
sedimentary sources located both in the Brasília and Araçuaí belts. The Tonian sources dated
around 950 Ma in sample FAS-LJ and also observed in samples GPP-M and LJ-A may come
from the Mayubian and Zanadian Groups and the Noqui granites dated between 912-1000 Ma
in the West-Congo orogen (Tack et al., 2001), but sources with these ages are also found in
254
the Goiás Magmatic arc in the Brasília Belt (Pimentel and Fuck, 1992). Sources dated around
800 Ma may come from metagranitoids of the Arenópolis arc of the Brasília belt dated at ca.
790 Ma (Laux et al., 2005). Sources with similar ages are also described in the Rio Negro
Complex, located at the Ribeira Belt to the south of the São Francisco craton (Tupinambá et
al., 2000; Heilbron and Machado, 2003). In conclusion, our data do not allow distinguishing
from which orogen the sediments came.
Seismic sections across the São Francisco basin suggest that the Brasília Belt is the
main source of sediments for the Bambuí Group, with the Araçuaí belt working mainly as a
deformer of the unit (Zalán and Romeiro-Silva, 2007). Nonetheless, the euhedral morphology
of the zircon grains from the Sete Lagoas Formation (Paula-Santos et al., 2015), the U-Pb
ages of detrital zircon grains of the Sete Lagoas and Serra da Saudade formations younger
than 540 Ma (Kuchenbecker, 2014; Paula-Santos et al., 2015) and the sedimentary
characteristics of the Três Marias Formation (Martins-Neto and Alkmim, 2001) are strong
evidences for the contribution of the Araçuaí belt contribution to the filling of the São
Francisco basin. The Cambrian ages are remarkable, as they are not reported for any
magmatism in the Brasília Belt with important implications for the São Francisco basin
evolution. They imply that the subsidence of the basin continued after the end of the tectonic
activity of the western orogen assumed in its currently accepted evolution (Pimentel et al.,
2016). We do not claim that the tectonic model of the Brasília Belt is flawed, as we have no
argument or data for such assumption. In the same way, the interpretation that the Bambuí
Group was deposited in a foreland basin in response to the western orogen crustal overload
cannot be dismissed as it is attested by the following features: (i) low Bouguer anomaly
values close and parallel to the Brasilia belt (Alkmim, 2004); (ii) distribution of depositional
systems of the Samburá Formation, which comprises fan deltas bringing sediments from the
Brasília belt rocks (Castro and Dardenne, 2000); (iii) tectonic imbrications between the
Brasília Belt and the Bambuí Group (Martins-Neto et al., 2001). Rather than that, we find that
refinements in the timing between the subsidence induced by the Brasília belt and the filling
of the São Francisco basin are required. Perhaps Late Ediacaran to Early Cambrian tectonic
events at the western margin of the São Francisco-Congo paleocontinent, such as
intracontinental orogeny (Meira et al., 2015) or the closure of the Clymene ocean (Trindade et
al., 2003), have influenced the deposition of the Bambuí Group.
Additionally, if the Araçuaí belt is indeed source to the Bambuí Group, our U-Pb data
and other data published so far for the basin may have implications for the eastern orogen. In
recent compilation of the U-Pb ages of detrital zircon from the Bambuí Group, Kuchenbecker
255
(2014) observed the Neoproterozoic sources of the unit have dominantly a Late Cryogenian to
Early Ediacaran age (~630 Ma) with very few Late Ediacaran to Early Cambrian ages, which
is consistent with the data obtained in this work. These younger sources are widely exposed in
the Araçuaí belt nowadays and are grouped in the G3, G4 and G5 supersuites (Pedrosa-Soares
et al., 2011). Considering the presence of the Cloudina sp. (Warren et al., 2014) and the age
of the occurrence of the index fossil between 550-542 Ma (Grotzinger et al., 2000), it seems
that G3 to G4 rocks were scarcely exposed during the deposition of the Bambuí Group,
although already crystallized. This suggests low denudation rates in the orogen and may
explain the lower contribution of the Araçuaí belt to the São Francisco basin filling compared
to the Brasília belt.
To summarize, the geochronological data obtained in this work point to only one
major reorganization in the source feeding the basin during the evolution of the São Francisco
basin. This event occurs between the conglomeratic and finer facies of the Carrancas
Formation and possibly in other correlates such as the Moema Laminites, and is interpreted as
an expansion of the sedimentation and the area feeding the basin due to the initial marine
transgression that flooded the São Francisco craton. In this scenario, the deposition initially
confined within the valleys extrapolated these areas depositing sediments derived from a
larger area. Unfortunately, our data do not allow distinguishing which sources were located in
the Brasília or in the Araçuaí belt. This question is yet to be answered and is crucial to solve
the geological puzzle involving the basin and its surrounding mobile belts.
5.2. Possible implications for the age of the glaciation
The age of the glacial unit at the base of the São Francisco basin remains
controversial, as several proposals from the Early Cryogenian (Sturtian age; Babinski et al.,
2007), Late Cryogenian (Marinoan age; Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2014; Uhlein et
al., 2016) to Late Ediacaran ages (~550 Ma; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016) were made.
The age of the middle portion of the Sete Lagoas Formation (CI-2 stage of Paula-
Santos et al., 2017) is constrained by the index fossil Cloudina sp. between 550-542 Ma
(Warren et al., 2014). The presence of detrital zircon grains younger than 540 Ma in the upper
Sete Lagoas (Paula-Santos et al., 2015) and in the Serra da Saudade formations
(Kuchenbecker, 2014) suggest that the deposition of the Bambuí Group spans through the
Cambrian. Assuming any of the Cryogenian ages for the glacial deposits, the Late Ediacaran
age for the base of the Bambuí Group imply that either the first 100 m of the Sete Lagoas
256
Formation records 85 or 200 Myr of deposition or an unconformity yet to be found exists
between the CI-1 and CI-2 carbonates. The first option is highly unlikely as such durations are
not compatible with a second order or a third order sequence (Vieira et al., 2007) subdivision
of the lower Sete Lagoas Formation (Vail et al., 1991). Here, we examine the second option
and its implications.
Stratigraphic (Kuchenbecker et al., 2016), sequence stratigraphic (Vieira et al., 2007)
and isotope chemostratigraphic data (Paula-Santos et al., 2017) argue against the existence of
an unconformity at the base of the Bambuí Group and suggest a continuous deposition
through the cap carbonates to the Cloudina bearing strata. We add to these arguments our Sm-
Nd data that also points to no major reorganization of the basin sources during this stage.
Assuming that no hiatus in the deposition exists means the glaciation may be Late Ediacaran
in age, following what was recently proposed by Kuchenbecker et al. (2016). As no very
negative ? 13
C values similar to the Shuram-Wonoka anomaly (Halverson et al., 2005; Le
Guerroué et al., 2006; Halverson and Hurtgen, 2007) is reported for the Bambuí Group, we
argue that the glaciation may be post-Gaskiers in age (? 582 Ma). Glaciations of this period
are recorded worldwide (e.g. Frimmel et al., 2006; Hebert et al., 2010; Germs and Gaucher,
2012; Ivanov et al., 2013; Etemad-Saeed et al., 2016), so the Bambuí would not be a sole
case.
If such unconformity exist and the glaciation is Cryogenian, than it is most likely
Sturtian (~740 Ma) as suggested by the only absolute age obtained so far for the cap
carbonates (Babinski et al., 2007). The lack of detrital zircon grains dated at ~630 Ma in the
glacial units (Buchwaldt et al., 1999; Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2008; Rodrigues, 2008; Babinski
et al., 2012; Guacaneme et al., submitted) is also an indicative for an Early Cryogenian age, as
sources of this age are reported in both Araçuaí (Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011) and Brasília
Belts (Pimentel et al., 2016) and were expected to appear in Late Cryogenian sedimentary
rocks.
The Marinoan age proposition relies in three pieces of evidence. First, in the 87
Sr/ 86
Sr
ratios around 0.7075 usually reported for the Sete Lagoas Formation (Alvarenga et al., 2007,
2014; Misi et al., 2007; Paula-Santos et al., 2015), which were interpreted to reflect global
seawater values after the Marinoan period (Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2014). This
interpretation was ruled out by Paula-Santos et al. (2017) that showed that these Sr isotopic
ratios are result of restriction and local factors, and therefore cannot be used for global
correlations. The second evidence is the negative C isotope excursion observed in the cap
carbonates (Alvarenga et al., 2007; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016) which is more typical of post-
257
Marinoan cap carbonates (Hoffman and Schrag, 2002; Halverson et al., 2005). We note that
such excursion was recently reported for cap carbonates overlying glacial deposits with a
maximum depositional age of 560 Ma in Iran (Etemad-Saeed et al., 2016) and is also
expected for many glacial periods through the Ediacaran (Hebert et al., 2010). The final
evidence is the very positive ? 13
C values of carbonate rocks of the Carrancas Formation that
were correlated to the pre-Marinoan “Keele Peak” (Uhlein et al., 2016). Again, these ? 13
C
values are also observed in Ediacaran carbonate successions and precede negative C isotope
excursions up to the Ediacaran-Cambrian Boundary (Pelechaty et al., 1996; Saylor et al.,
1998; Hebert et al., 2010). We do not completely rule out the Marinoan age for the base of the
São Francisco basin glacial deposits, but we note that the evidence so far does not allow us to
distinguish a Marinoan glaciation from an Ediacaran one, what ultimately may serve as
another argument for a Late Ediacaran age possibility for such rocks. Nevertheless, if an
unconformity exists, we stick to the only absolute age available to claim the glaciation is
Sturtian in age.
6. Conclusions
The new geochronological data obtained in this work provided further insights in the
evolution of the São Francisco basin. Based on the Sm-Nd, U-Pb and Hf isotope data of
siliciclastic rocks we state the following:
- The Sm-Nd isotope data from the lower glacial units and from the Bambuí Group
show only one major reorganization of the sedimentary sources through the evolution of the
São Francisco basin. This is observed in the transition from the conglomerates to the finer
sediments in the Carrancas Formation and Moema Laminites, in which the TDM ages abruptly
fall from 2.7-3.3 Ga to ages younger than 2.1 Ga and the ?Nd(550 Ma) values increase from lower
than -17 to higher than -10. These isotope data reflect the change in the sedimentation initially
confined to basement valleys, with sediments coming exclusively from the Archean rocks of
the valley walls, to a wider basin area with deposition of the finer sediments and a larger
source area. During the latter stage, the São Francisco basin received sediments not only from
homonymous craton basement, but also from rocks located in the marginal mobile belts.
- TDM ages between 1.3 and 2.1 Ga and ?Nd(550 Ma) values between –9.53 to -4.09 are
constantly observed from the siltites and claystones of the Carrancas Formation and the
Moema Laminites up to the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation of the Bambuí Group, without
258
significant variations. This adds another argument to support the lack of an unconformity
between the lower glacial units and the Bambuí Group. Based on the presence of the index
fossil Cloudina sp. in the lower Sete Lagoas Formation, the glaciation recorded in the São
Francisco basin is most likely Late Ediacaran in age. Nevertheless, if the unconformity exists,
we stick to the only absolute age obtained so far to claim it is Sturtian in age, as the arguments
based on chemostratigraphy cannot distinguish a Marinoan from a Late Ediacaran glaciation.
- Our geochronological data do not allow tracking whether the Ediacaran sources are
located in the Brasília or in the Araçuaí belt. The contribution of the Araçuaí belt to the filling
of the basin is evidenced by the presence of detrital zircon grains with U-Pb ages younger
than 540 Ma in the Bambuí Group in other locations that are not found in any igneous source
of the Brasília belt. These younger ages also require better refinements in the timing between
the flexural subsidence and filling of the basin.
